docs.title: Home
docs.text:
Welcome to the almighty doc.jp! This is a central place to keep track of my Japanese learning journey (resources, goals, etc.).

If you happen to stumble across this site and find something that is useful for you, please use it! It should be noted that this site is mostly intended for me and not for a broader audience; you can think of this site as being mostly a blog of sorts.

docs.title: My Japanese learning journey
docs.text:
I started learning Japanese on 08/21/2023.

My first few months learning the language were somewhat all over the place. While I have 6+ months of learning time, I feel like I've just started to find my footing with learning Japanese.

docs.title: Why did I start learning Japanese?
docs.text:
Well, I shamelessly started learning Japanese as I love the persona video game series. Persona 5 is what initially sparked the interest.

However, this initial interest was fairly weak (I liked the idea of knowing Japanese, but not enough to spend the thousands of hours it would take to become proficient in Japanese), and I ended up quitting twice before.

Nowadays, I continue to learn Japanese as I fell in love with the language (I also still enjoy Japanese media). It's a really pretty language in every facet (spoken, read, etc.). Japan is also a really pretty country, and I want to visit and explore it one day.

docs.title: Goals
docs.text: A big part of keeping my studies interesting is setting realistic goals. I house my goals in a separate section which can be found here

docs.title: Resources
docs.text: I tend to use a lot of different resources and I like to keep track of them all. They can be found in a separate page here.

docs.title: Study Plan
docs.text: I like to formulate a general plan for myself in terms of studying. I will sometimes veer off this, but try and update it when I can. Regardless, this can be found here.

docs.title: My Japanese Language Learning Goals
docs.text: Goals are super important! To keep my learning journey fresh and interesting (and to remember why I'm doing what I'm doing in the first place), I like to set realistic goals. The goals section of the site is dedicated to this purpose.

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
I structure the goals section into 4 categories: Long term goals, Goals for the year, Monthly goals, and Legacy goals.

All types of goals can be navigated to by using the navigation bar on the left hand side of the screen.

docs.title: Long term goals
docs.text: Long term goals are goals I want to achieve in the far future (most of which require a certain level of proficiency to achieve).

docs.title: Goals for the year
docs.text: I think it's important to set yearly goals in addition to monthly goals. That's the purpose of this page.

docs.title: Monthly goals
docs.text: Of course, the meat and potatoes for the most part are my monthly goals. Every month I add a page for the current months goals. I then move the previous month to the legacy goals section.

docs.title: Legacy goals
docs.text: This section houses the goals I had from previous months. I liked the idea of being able to go back and observe my progress over time.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This is where I'll house my long term goals for learning Japanese.

docs.title: Goals
docs.text:
• Take and Pass the JLPT N3
  • Play Persona 5 Royal in Japanese with Japanese Subtitles by my 29th birthday
  • Watch Parasyte: The Maxim in japanese with Japanese subtitles by my 29th birthday

docs.title: December 2023 Goals
docs.text: • Finish N5 Grammar on Bunpro

docs.title: November 2023 Goals
docs.text:
Success

All complete

  • Review grammar on bunpro everyday
  • Do at least 5 cram study sessions on currently known grammar on bunpro
  • Study 10 new vocab every day

docs.title: Stretch Goal
docs.text: • Finish Japanese From Zero book 3 (might not get to until December as I want to focus mostly on grammar review this month)

docs.title: October 2023 Goals
docs.text:
Success

All complete

  • Finish Japanese From Zero book 2~~: Finished
  • Learn 300 vocabulary words 10 per day (will bring me to 569 vocabulary words learned)
  • Immerse with two episodes of Laid Back Camp (Yuru Camp)

ALL COMPLETE

docs.title: Goals
docs.text:
• Finish Genki 2

  • Immerse in 100 hours of content

docs.title: Stretch Goals
docs.text: None at the moment

docs.title: February 2024 Goals
docs.text:
• Immerse with comprehensible input at least 30 minutes per day
  • Do at least 2 new chapters of genki 2

docs.title: January 2024 Goals
docs.text: • Finish Genki 1 and all workbook work

docs.title: Grammar
docs.text: So, as of right now. I'm not really sure what I want to house here. If there is a specific grammar point I'm struggling with, I might just display those.

docs.title: Study Plan
docs.text:
This is a place to formulate some thoughts on my intended path going forward (related to my studies). This changes frequently; however, the plan section will always have the date at which I updated it last. My plan can sometimes change a bit between documentation updates (documentation changes take time away from studying); however, it's typically what my current plan is at the moment.

Important

Some of the wording in this plan will seem like I'm directing the explanation outward (for external use). However, it's mostly so I fully understand what my plan is and why I'm doing it that way.

If you happen to be reading this and it does provide some value to you, please use it. However, it should be noted that this plan is for me personally and is subject to change.

docs.title: Plan as of 02/12/2024
docs.text: Working through Genki 2 and the refold JP1k deck. I'm also immersing at least 30 minutes a day (mostly youtube right now - once without subtitles and once with Japanese subtitles)

docs.title: Currently Using
docs.text:
Important

I add and remove items from here all the time. I'm finding new resources all the time so I will update this page monthly so it's not always correct.

docs.title: Browser Extensions
docs.text:
• Yomitan: Yomitan is a browser extension that allows you to look up Japanese words with both the meaning and the reading on web pages with ease. I use it primarily for quickly looking up definitions (not for mining) when I'm reading.

  • Migaku: Honestly, it's mostly just a sentence mining thing for me. I prefer it over using yomitan and asbplayer. Might change in the future though.

  • Language Reactor: Kind of like migaku or yomitan in a way. Embeds directly to youtube or netflix (there are others). I like it for just reading subtitles on youtube and not for mining (I like reading subtitles with this on youtube better than yomitan as there's a list of all the subtiles in a panel on the right similar to asbplayer).

docs.title: Grammar
docs.text:
• Genki 2 (Grammar textbook)

  • Bunpro: Pretty cool. Groups grammar points by N~ level or by textbook. Will essentially make the equivalent of an Anki deck in the UI. I use it more so for repetition but I learn from textbooks.

docs.title: Input
docs.text:
• Mokuro: This is a web based catalog with a huge selection of manga that's parsable with yomitan! I really enjoy using this to read manga.

  • Satori Reader: I really like this service. It essentially just a site with tons of graded stories. However, the sentence by sentence translation and native audio make the whole service very nice to use.

  • Comprehensible Japanese on YouTube: She has amazing comprehensible japanese videos. I really enjoy watching them and they've helped quite a bit.

  • Akiko Japanese Conversations on YouTube: Another great channel with really good comprehensible japanese.

docs.title: Dictionaries
docs.text:
• Jotoba: A really helpful dictionary I prefer over Jisho at times.

  • Jisho: Tried and true lookup dictionary.

docs.title: Sentence Search
docs.text: • Immersion Kit: Made by game gengo (amazing youtuber!). You can search sentences from anime, games, etc. with translation. I like to use it when I want to spice up the sentences I'm mining (for a particular vocabulary word)

docs.title: Misc
docs.text: • Japanese Media Recommendation Spreadsheet: This has been super helpful when picking resources to get input from

docs.title: Not Using Currently
docs.text:
Important

I add and remove items from here all the time. I'm finding new resources all the time so I will update this page monthly so it's not always correct.

I'm also not listing textbooks on the not using page.

  • Genki Study Resources By Seth Clydesdale: Amazing resource if you're going through Genki 1. Has a ton of practice for all lessons of Genki 1

docs.title: Graded Readers
docs.text:
• Tadoku Graded Readers: Free graded books

  • NHK Easy News: Essentially a graded reader but with Japanese news

docs.title: Browser Extensions
docs.text: • Asbplayer: Load local subtitle files to video streaming sites.

docs.title: Dictionaries
docs.text:
• jpdb: Have pretty cool features. Also cool for generated Anki decks for anime, novels, etc. Essentially allowing you to skip sentence mining. My favorite feature is you can paste an entire article from somewhere like nhk easy news and it will make an entire deck from it with all the vocab.

  • Tokoboto: Another dictionary I like to use from time to time. Not as much as the other two however

docs.title: TV / Movies
docs.text:
• Kitsunekko: Probably the biggest collection of Japanese subtitles for anime. An absolute lifesaver for immersion.

  • Super Native: Cool site that trains you to hear, read, and speak Japanese from TV and movies.

  • Aniwatch.to: Anime streaming site (mostly use for anime that isn't on any streaming platforms like Crunchyroll, Hidive, Amazon, etc.)

  • Aniwave.to: Anime streaming site (mostly use for anime that isn't on any streaming platforms like Crunchyroll, Hidive, Amazon, etc.)

  • Animelon: Can actually stream anime with Japanese subtitles which is pretty cool. Don't use it a ton but.

docs.title: Games
docs.text: • Game2Text: Essentially adds the ability to parse Japanese from games

docs.title: Kanji
docs.text: • Kanji Map: Really cool resource for learning stroke patterns

docs.title: Podcasts
docs.text: • Japanese Podcast Spreadsheet: Has a huge list of podcasts in Japanese. There's also a list (starter pack), that's sorted by Japanese level.

docs.title: Sentence Search
docs.text: • Youglish: Sentences sourced from YouTube video subtitles. Great tool for pronunciation as the words are said by native speakers speaking naturally.

docs.title: Grammar
docs.text: • TokiniAndy Course: He has free youtube videos but the course is amazing. Has graded readers, shadowing practice, vocabulary review, textbook lesson and practice (Genki), and more. I'm not using it anymore as I'm following a different book than genki now.
